Misbah is a 43-year-old married woman and a mother of three children. She is a hardworking and independent mother who is helping her family by providing services of tailoring. She has been doing it for the past few years. She is very well known about the techniques of stitching. She sews garments of nearest factories; her husband brings cloths from the factory and she provide tailoring services at her home.  
To help her continue operations of her business, she has requested a loan to buy a sewing machine because her previous sewing machine has become out of order due to continuously working. In addition to repaying the loan; she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.
Misbah thanks to Kiva and field partner, brac Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy sewing machine for sewing cloths.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 18 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Caroline has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells drinks. 

To help expand her business, Caroline has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sodas, beer, and spirits for the bar to sell, which will help Caroline to generate greater profits and buy things for the family's basic needs. Caroline hopes that in the future she will be able to own a beauty salon. 

Caroline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sodas, beer, and spirits for the bar to sell

loans.name: Saphina's Group

texts.en:
Saphina's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Saphina is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, she has been working hard to manage her food stall. 

To help expand her business, Saphina has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more raw food to sell at her stall, and will help Saphina to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child and her sister's child. She hopes that in the future she will be able to build a residential house. 

Saphina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more food to sell at her stall

loans.name: Zebo

texts.ru:
Зебо преподаватель с большим стажем. У нее высшее образование, она заканчивала Институт языков и в течение 20 лет преподает в средней школе своего маленького городка Нурек. Зебо 51 год. Она разведена и живет с двумя взрослыми сыновьями. Старший сын в данный момент безработный, а младший сын студент. Он учится в Таджикском Государственном Техническом Университете по специальности "Менеджмент и управление". Его годовое обучение в университете стоит около 900 долларов США. Сейчас Зебо нуждается в заемных средствах, чтобы оплатить за обучение сына. С такой целью она обратилась в организацию Хумо за кредитом для образования по низким процентным ставкам. Она берет кредит в размере 1000 долларов США, из них около 900 долларов пойдут на оплату годового контракта, а остальные деньги будут потрачены на учебные принадлежности. 
Зебо верит и надеется на поддержку.
texts.en: Zebo is a teacher with many years of experience. She has a college degree. She  has graduated from the Institute of Foreign Languages and has been teaching for 20 years at the secondary school in her small town, Nurek. Zebo is 51 years old. She is divorced and lives with her two adults sons. Her eldest son   is unemployed at present, and her youngest son is a student. He is studying at the Tajik State Technical University, majoring in Management and Business Administration. His annual university tuition costs about 900 USD. At present Zebo needs a loan in order to pay for her son’s education. This is why she has applied to the MLO Humo for a low-interest education loan. She is taking out a loan in the amount of 1,000 USD; about 900 USD will be used to settle the annual bill, and the rest used for textbooks and school supplies. Zebo truly hopes to get support.

loans.use: to pay for her son's university tuition and buy textbooks and school supplies.

loans.name: Velonica

texts.en:
Velonica is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past year, Velonica has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Velonica has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell, and this will help Velonica to generate greater profits and improve on her family's standard of living. Velonica hopes that in the future she will be able to stop the mobile business and rent a shop for her business. 

Velonica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a hardworking woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past year, Judith has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells passion juice, sodas, and oranges. 

To help expand her business, Judith has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy passion juice, sodas, and oranges and will help Judith to generate greater profits and pay her house rent. Judith hopes that in the future, she will be able to open a retail shop. 

Judith is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy passion juice, sodas, and oranges

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma's Group is a group of hardworking women. Fatuma is 22 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her drugstore where she sells medicine. 

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicine and will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and provide for her parents. Fatuma hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand to a big pharmacy. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more medicine

loans.name: Djidja Group

texts.fr:
Djidja est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et ont au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, de Fruits et légumes, Habillement, Ustensiles de cuisine, Condiments et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  troisième prêt de groupe. 
Aminata  est un membre du groupe Djidja, debout au bout et à gauche, vendeuse de Fruits et légumes (mangues, Bananes, orange et divers). Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des fruits et légumes (mangues, bananés, orange et divers)  en qualité et en quantité au fur et à mesure  qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse. Elle se procure au grand marché. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Djidja comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100 000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Aminata compte réaliser  120 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Djidja is a group of women from Koutiala who live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They know each other well. They average 34 years of age and four children each. 

These women are resellers or various goods such as fruits and vegetables, clothing, kitchen utensils, condiments, and miscellaneous other items. To bolster their activities, the group members joined the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. This is their 3rd group loan cycle. 

Aminata, the Djidja group member standing at the far left, is a reseller of fruits and vegetables. She plans to use her loan to replenish her stock of good quality mangos, bananas, oranges and others as it gets sold; she buys her fruits and vegetables at the big market and sells it at retail to a diverse clientele. 

The other group members expect to earn an average profit of 100,000CFA each during this loan cycle. As for Aminata, she expects her profit to reach 120,000FCFA.

In addition to loan repayment, they will use part of their revenue to cover personal expenses and to bolster their working capital.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal is a hard-working woman. Racheal is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro, in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past three years, Racheal has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, in which she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Racheal has requested a loan of UGX 700,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes and will help Racheal to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Racheal hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a boutique. 

Racheal is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Triunfadores De Quellomayo Group

texts.es:
La socia Teodocia pertenece al banco comunal TRIUNFADORES DE QUELLOMAYO, el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Vilcabamba, provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.
La socia Teodocia tiene 50 años de edad, tiene 03 hijos y es conviviente, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose a la agricultura, la socia cultiva café frutas entre otros, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abono entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
Los demás socios también se dedican a la agricultura.
texts.en:
Teodocia belongs to the communal bank "TRIUNFADORES DE QUELLOMAYO", which is located in Vilcabamba District, in La Convención Province in the department of Cusco. She is 50 years old, is in a relationship, and has three children. She manages both her daily activities and agricultural work. She grows coffee and fruit, among others. She has had this business for some time and it is going well for her, thanks to the hard work she puts into it every day. She hopes to be able to continue working so that she can continue to support her family.

Teodocia is requesting this loan to buy fertilizers and manure, among others. She is grateful for the loan and promises to make her payments on time.

The other members of the group also work in agriculture.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and manure.

loans.name: Jaminah's Group

texts.en:
Jaminah's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Jaminah is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Jaminah has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetic body lotions to sell, which will help her to generate greater profits and buy a plot of land. Jaminah hopes that in the future she will be able to improve her family's standard of living. 

Jaminah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more cosmetic body lotions to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy electrical appliances (stove and fridge) and to buy furniture (for the living and dining rooms).

loans.name: Fresia Haydee

texts.es:
Fresia es una joven emprendedora, tiene 47 años de edad, vive en el Distrito de ocuaje junto a su familia.
Tiene una hija quien es su mayor orgullo y por quien ha salido adelante sola ya que es madre soltera, pero eso no fue impedimento para que pudiera sobresalir.
Desde hace 4 años trabaja brindando servicio de Catering a los diferentes eventos que puedan realizarse en la ciudad donde vive. Se ha convertido en una persona exitosa porque brinda un servicio de calidad a un precio cómodo.
Fresia está agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado ella podrá comprar una cama y colchón para poder sentir mayor comodidad y seguir esforzándose para cumplir su más grande sueño: "Que su hija sea una gran profesional".
texts.en:
Fresia is a young entrepreneur. She is 47 years old and lives in the Ocucaje district with her family. Her daughter is her pride and joy and the reason that she has moved forward alone, since she is a single mother. However, this was not an obstacle for her to overcome.

Four years ago, she began providing catering services to different events in the city where she lives. She has become a successful person because she provides high quality services at a good price.

Fresia is grateful to Kiva lenders because, due to their support, she will be able to purchase a bed and mattresses so that she can be more comfortable and continue working hard to achieve her greatest dream: "for her daughter to become a great professional."

loans.use: to purchase a bed and mattresses.

loans.name: Ramiro

texts.es: El señor Ramiro vive en Tiraque, se dedica a la producción agrícola, el señor no cuenta con muchos recursos económicos, es de estado civil soltero pero vive en concubinato y tiene un hijo que depende de sus ingresos, demuestra ser muy trabajador y tiene muchas ganas de superarse, trabaja en la actividad económica agrícola como actividad primaria, para la siembra y cosecha utiliza personal eventual que son sus vecinos, no tiene casa propia vive en la casa de su madre y desde sus niñez la ayuda porque su padre los abandono, para la producción agrícola utiliza tracción animal. Ahora se ve en la necesidad de solicitar un crédito para compra de ganado bovino de esta forma aumentara su producción y lograra mejorar sus ingresos y la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Ramiro lives in Tiraque. He makes a living in agriculture and does not have many economic resources. He is not married but has a common-law wife and a child that depends his income. Ramiro is very hard-working and wants to succeed. He works in agriculture as his primary activity and, for sowing and harvesting, he uses temporary help from his neighbors.

Ramiro does not have a house of his own; he lives in his mother´s house and, since childhood, he has helped her because his father abandoned them. 

He uses animal-drawn equipment for farming. Now he needs to ask for a loan to buy cattle. In this way, he will increase production and will be able to improve his income and the quality of life of his family.

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Los Pilares  (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En el sector conocido como 4 esquinas en la parroquia Colón de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen cada quince días los socios del Grupo De Crédito Los Pilares. Los mismos que se dedican a diversas actividades tales como la agricultura o el comercio en general. Ellos decidieron unirse para poder acceder a los beneficios que presta la institución y con los créditos mejorar sus negocios.
Uno de los socios de este grupo es don Idaudo, tiene 53 años de edad, está casado y de esta relación tienen tres hijas mayores e independientes. Su esposa es comerciante.
El señor Idaudo es un hombre muy trabajador que le gusta a base de esfuerzo sacar adelante a su familia, el junto a  la esposa tienen una tienda de víveres en su casa donde venden todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad, el necesita este crédito para invertir una parte en su tienda de víveres y la otra para comprar tres chanchos los cuales espera criar por espacio de unos 4 meses y luego cuando tengan un peso adecuado venderlos a comerciantes de la localidad. Ellos tienen más de 10 años su tienda y esperan que con la cría de los chanchos mejorar sus ingresos.
Este crédito es para comprar víveres para la tienda y tres chanchos para la cría. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos son de mucha ayuda. Sus sueños son seguir adelante y mejorar su tienda.
texts.en:
In the sector of the Colón parish of the city of Portoviejo known as 4 Corners, the members of the Los Pilares credit group meet every 15 days. They work in various businesses, like agriculture, or general commerce. They decided to band together in order to access the benefits that the institution provides and improve their businesses with loans.

One of the members is Idaudo. He is married and has three adult children. His wife is a merchant. Idaudo is a very hardworking man who enjoys moving his family forward by working hard. 

With his wife, he has a supply store in his home, where he sells various types of household goods. He needs this loan so that he can invest part of it in his store, and he will use the other part to purchase three pigs. He hopes to raise the pigs for four months and then, when they are the right weight, sell them to local merchants.

They have worked at their store for more than ten years and hope that raising pigs will increase their income. This loan is to purchase supplies for the store and three pigs to raise. He has been a part of the credit group since it began and likes it because the loans are very helpful. His dreams are to move forward and improve his store.

loans.use: to purchase supplies and three pigs.

loans.name: Heriberto

texts.es:
Heriberto tiene 44 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, vive en una comunidad de Lagunas, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

El se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado caprino desde hace 03 años, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 500 nuevos soles para la compra y venta de ganado caprino y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Heriberto is 44 years old, is single, and lives with his partner. He lives in the Lagunas community, whose residents make a living through agriculture, commerce, and ranching. It is located in the Chiclayo Province, which belongs to the Lambayeque region on Perú's northern coast.

He has made a living by purchasing and selling cattle and goats for the past three years. He requests a loan for 1,500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to purchase and sell cattle and goats so that he can earn more money for his family.

loans.use: to purchase cattle, goats, sheep, etc.

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Criselda works hard to support her family.

She has a cafe in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fattening pigs. Criselda is borrowing PHP 7,000 through NWTF in order to buy sugar, milk, coffee, and other ingredients for her cafe.

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy sugar, milk, coffee, and other ingredients

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 64 years old, married and has nine children. 

Lucia grows rice in the Philippines. Lucia requested 7,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fertilizer for her farm.

Lucia has grown rice for twenty years and has previously borrowed one time from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Lucia would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards.
Besides the clothes selling business, Catherine sells eggs. She is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of eggs for resale .Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more crates of eggs for resale

loans.name: Ismary

texts.es: Ismary es una mujer de 24 años de edad, que habita con su cónyuge y su pequeña hija de 6 años de edad al suroccidente de la ciudad.  Desde Enero del año 2010 unos amigos le sugirieron dedicarse al servicio de alquiler de maquinas para lavar, para atender la demanda del barrio y ella entusiamada accedió y posteriormente aprovechando su clientela empezó a venderle mercancias a la medida de sus necesidades, con lo cual empezó a generar ingresos adicionales; hoy cuenta con sus dos negocios y le invierte a los dos, porque  con el alquiler de lavadoras,  rotar su efectivo y obtiene liquidéz permanete, mientras que con el de venta de mercancias,   mantiene cuentas por cobrar, con las que incrementa su capital, debido que las  ventas a crédito le producen un mayor margen de utilidades y lo que necesita justamente Ismary, es maximisar sus ingreso. Sus principales clientes se encuentran en le barrio donde habita, su meta es tener un almacen abierto al público y garantizar una educacion de calidad a su hija. Su mayor desafio es lograr incrementar sus ventas, fidelizar a su clientela con buena atención y con muy buenos precios. En la actualidad Ismary está aplicando a un credikiva, primer finaciamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual reparará sus lavadoras y comprará mercancias, como jeanes, calzado perfumería etc. Con esta inversión, planea mejorar su negocio, porque aumentarían sus ventas y sus utilidades.
texts.en:
Ismary is 24 years old and lives with her partner and six-year-old daughter in the south-west of Barranquilla. In January 2010, Ismary's friends suggested that she start a business renting out washing machines, in order to meet demand in the community. Ismary enthusiastically agreed and later decided also to sell merchandise to her customers; this allowed her to earn a little more money.

Ismary now has her two businesses. She has accounts that customers need to pay, allowing her to increase capital. Sales on credit give Ismary higher profits, which allows her to maximise her income. Ismary's main customers live in the community. Ismary's goal is to have a large store open for the public, and to guarantee her daughter a good-quality education. Ismary's biggest challenges are increasing sales and gaining loyalty from her customers with good service and affordable prices.

Ismary is currently applying for a Kiva loan, the first she has taken out through "Fundación Mario Santo Domingo". With this loan, Ismary will repair her washing machines and buy merchandise, such as jeans, footwear, perfumes and more. This investment will allow Ismary to improve her business as sales and profits will increase.

loans.use: to repair her washing machines and buy merchandise, such as jeans, footwear, perfumes and more.

loans.name: Priscar

texts.en:
Priscar appreciates her previous loan, which improved her standard of living. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.
Besides the charcoal-selling business,Priscar operates a vegetable stall. She would like to apply for a loan to buy vegetables for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy vegetables for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his brother's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of grains and groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: A portion of Sadia's Group $ 3,000 loan is to buy sewing machine and fabric.

loans.name: Orlando De Jesus

texts.es:
El señor Orlando es un hombre muy emprendedor y activo. Tiene 65 años, vive en la ciudad de Medellín y tiene 4 hijos a los cuales ha dedicado gran parte de su vida. Se siente orgulloso al saber que ha podido levantar a sus hijos con amor e inculcándoles buenos valores.
Él se dedica a la venta de un líquido que sirve para brillar materiales en aluminio, el mismo lo fabrica y lo comercializa en diferentes municipios del departamento de Antioquia.
Tiene como objetivo abrir un local en cual pueda exhibir y vender todos sus productos.
El solicita un préstamo para la compra de materia prima que consiste básicamente en algunos químicos especiales que el maneja apropiadamente, al comprarlos al por mayor podrá obtener unos mejores descuentos.
El crédito le permitirá tener un mejor capital de trabajo impulsando así su idea de negocio.
texts.en:
Orlando is an energetic and entrepreneurial man. He is 65 years old and lives in the city of Medellín. He has four children and has spent most of his life working hard to raise them. He feels proud of having been able to raise his children with love and good values.

Orlando sells a liquid used to polish aluminum objects. He produces it and sells it in different municipalities of the Antioquia department. His goal is to open a store where he can display and sell his products.

Orlando is requesting a loan to buy the ingredients he needs, which are basically chemicals. He is careful when using them and will buy them wholesale in order to receive a discount.

This loan will increase his working capital and will help him to get ahead with his business idea.

loans.use: to buy chemicals to produce metal polish.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: A portion of Kwestan's Group's $ 4,500 loan intends a member to pay for her brother’s education.

loans.name: Marleny Beatriz

texts.es:
Marleny es madre soltera y orgullosa de un hijo de 5 años de edad, al ver que el padre de su hijo la abandonaba decidió tener el coraje de asumir toda la responsabilidad de su hogar y cuidar de su hijo a costa de lo que sea.
Ella trabaja actualmente como comerciante de productos de la marca Herbalife, hace 2 años y medio inicio con esta actividad motivada por una amiga. Ya que no tenía más opciones y tenía un hijo pequeño que necesitaba recursos para su manutención opto por vender estos productos aun sin tener ningún tipo de estudio en la materia comercial.
Hoy en dia es una microempresaria feliz, agradece la oportunidad que la Corporación Interactuar le ha brindado para salir adelante y saborear el progreso.
Ella solicita un apoyo económico para comprar una gran cantidad de productos de la reconocida marca y poder tener un stock mucho más amplio para sus clientes.
Sueña con ser una empresaria exitosa y con ingresos estables para su familia.
texts.en:
Marleny is a single and proud mother to one five-year-old son. When her son's father abandoned the family, Marleny had the courage to take on the responsibility of her household no matter what.

Marleny is currently a businesswoman; for two years she has been selling Herbalife products, having been encouraged to go into the business by a friend. With no other options, and a young son who needed for different things, Marleny decided to start selling these goods, even though she had never studied for working in sales.

Now Marleny is a happy small-business own. She is grateful to "Interactuar" for this opportunity to prosper, and is enjoying making progress.

Marleny is applying for financial support in order to buy a large quantity of Herbalife products, and to be able to have a much great level of stock for her customers.

Marleny dreams of being a successful businesswoman with a stable income for her family.

loans.use: to buy Herbalife products to sell.

loans.name: Hashira's Group

texts.en:
Hashira's group is comprised of hard working women. Hashira is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Hashira has been working hard to manage her carpentry business, which makes and sells beds, chairs, and tables. 

To help expand her business, Hashira has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber to make furniture, which will help Hashira to generate greater profits and save money for an electric machine. Hashira hopes that in the future she will be able to complete a family house. 

Hashira is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more timber

loans.name: Mageli's Group

texts.en:
Mageli's group is comprised of hard working women. Mageli is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Mageli has been working hard to manage her business, which sells produce. 

To help expand her business, Mageli has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more produce to sell, which will help Mageli to generate greater profits. Mageli hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Mageli is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Fatuma is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her business, which sells dry coffee and sugarcane. 

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy coffee stems for planting and sugar cane to sell, which will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living and pay school fees for her child. Fatuma hopes that in the future she will be able to take a tailoring course. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy coffee stems for planting and sugar cane to sell

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda is a hardworking 17-year-old who lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. Single and  without children, for the past two years Brenda has been working hard to manage her business, which sells posho, rice, sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand her business, Brenda has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to buy more posho, rice, sugar, soap and salt; these purchases will help her to generate greater profits and pay for rent. She hopes in the future to expand her enterprise into a retail shop. 

Brenda is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy posho, rice, sugar, soap and salt

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a 19-year=old hard working woman who lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. 

For the past 3 years, Aisha has worked hard to manage her tailoring business. 

Aisha has requested 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase fabric and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and buy food. Aisha hopes that in the future, she will be able to open a retail shop. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase fabric.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola is a 16-year-old hard working woman who lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. 

For the past year, Viola has worked hard to manage her business to sell charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Viola has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sacks of charcoal, and will help Viola to generate greater profits and pay her rent. Viola hopes that in the future, she will be able to save money and open a savings account. 

Viola is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de femmes du Hamdallaye Extension de  Koutiala  qui se connaissent bien et qui  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et ont au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, d’Habillement, Beurre de Karité, Savons et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  deuxième prêt de groupe. 
Fatoumata est un membre du groupe Danaya assise juste au milieu, vendeuse des Habits. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter ces habits au près des grossistes  en qualité et en quantité au fur et à mesure  qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse. Elle se procure à Koutiala. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90.000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Fatoumata compte réaliser  100.000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Danaya Group is a group of women from Koutiala's Hamdallaye Extension who know one another well and who live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. On average, they are 33 years old and have at least five children.

This group of women is in business selling various goods, such as clothing, shea butter, soap, etc. In order to increase the size of their businesses, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. They are on their second group loan.

Fatoumata is a member of Danaya Group, seated in the middle [of the photo], who sells clothing. She plans to use her loan to purchase this clothing, gradually improving in quality and increasing in quantity, from wholesalers to sell at retail prices to a diverse group of customers. She gets her supplies in Koutiala.

While the other members of the Danaya Group [typically] expect to see an average profit of 90,000 CFA francs, Mrs. Fatoumata expects a profit of 100,000 CFA francs during this loan cycle. In addition to repaying the loans, the group members use part of this income to see to personal expenses and to expand their businesses. They wish to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to maintain consistent [levels] of stock.

loans.use: To purchase clothing.

loans.name: Zaitun

texts.en:
Zaituna is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Zaituna has worked hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Zaituna has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar and salt for the business, and will help Zaituna to generate greater profits and improve on her family's standard of living and school fees for her sister's son. Zaituna hopes that, in the future she will be able to start a beauty salon. 

She is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy sugar and salt for the business,

loans.name: Moureen

texts.en:
Moureen is a 16-year-old hard working woman who lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, Moureen has worked hard to manage her business to sell charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Moureen has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy bulk quantities of charcoal, and will help Moureen to generate greater profits and to meet her family's essential needs. Moureen hopes that, in the future she will be able to start another business. 

She is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy bulk quantities of charcoal.

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella is 52 years old, married and has two children. 

Estella raises pigs in the Philippines. Estella requested 12,000 PHP through NWTF  to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Estella has raised pigs for four years and has previously borrowed three times  from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Estella would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
It's one thing to have a chicken farm, but to start an actual business out of it is something else entirely. Isaac is a chicken farmer, but he wants to be a business person as well. He is a father of 4 and has practiced mixed farming for the last 30 years!

To earn a decent living, he sells milk, eggs, tea, greens, and engages in numerous small personal businesses. 

He recently started earning a profit from his poultry farm. Selling eggs became something of a hobby. He wanted to sell more but was constrained by the quantity. His biggest challenge today is limited funds to expand.

Isaac is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders via Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry. Isaac wants to purchase layers to fully tap into the chicken industry that is currently booming. 

Proceeds from poultry farming will be used to satisfy his family and business needs in future. His mission is to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
This is Beatrice. She previously accessed a loan that she used in her poultry business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She is requesting a loan to purchase chicks and poultry feed for her business. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support.. 

She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed for her business

loans.name: Rodalyn

texts.en:
Rodalyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Rodalyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like shampoo, soap, snack foods and other groceries. She has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Rodalyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like shampoo, soap, snack foods and other groceries.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 49 years old and has two children.  Elsie is married and both of her children attend school.

Elsie grows rice in the Philippines and requests 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

Elsie has grown rice for ten years and has previously borrowed five times from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Elsie would like to save enough money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Maa Saraswati Group

texts.en:
In the year 2014, twelve active women from Nilji village of Nuapada district in Odisha, India formed a group named Maa Saraswati to access loans from Mahashakti Foundation and expand their businesses. Nilji village is a remotely located rural village situated about 100 kilometers away from the district headquarters.  Ranjita is one of them. The 32-year-old cheerful lady sitting with raised hand in the photo is Ranjita. She   lives with her husband, one son of nine years and one daughter of fourteen years. Her daughter is studying in 10th standard in the local government school and her son is studying in 4th standard in a private school located in the village.

Ranjita is running a general grocery shop in her village for the last ten years with the help of her husband. She started the business with a very small investment of her own on limited items, i.e. potatoes, sugar, tea leaves, soap, shampoo, biscuits, etc. At that time her monthly net income was around 2,000 INR. With this small income it was very difficult on her part to maintain the family. Using small savings  she gradually expanded her business and now she is earning a monthly income of 8,000 INR. With this income, Ranjita is managing her family expenses as best she can, but facing financial trouble for the educational expenses of her children. 

With the intervention of Mahashakti Foundation, Ranjita saw a ray of hope.Her group approached Mahashakti Foundation and  availed a group  loan of 192000 INR. Out of this amount Ranjita took a loan of  16,000 INR. With a part of this loan she is planning to pay the admission fees of her son and daughter and with the other part wants to purchase items like rice, wheat, lentils, oil, soap, potatoes, etc. for her general store. This loan gave a solace to Ranjita as she has been able to arrange the money for the continued study of her children. Ranjita hopes to save enough for the better education of her children and purchase a new bike for her husband.

The other eleven members of the group are managing a general store business, a fabrication center, a betel shop, a tailoring center, milk selling, vegetable vending, a Tiffin (tea) stall, an egg center, etc.

loans.use: To pay the primary school admission fees of her son, secondary school admission fees of her daughter and  purchase items for her general store.

loans.name: Balasan

texts.en:
Balasan is from Gyumri town and lives with her three school-aged children. Her husband is a migrant worker in a neighboring country. Balasan runs a small bakery. She is involved in Armenian bread (lavash) production. She sells it to local small stores and gathers income for her family.

Balasan requested this loan to be able to purchase materials and tools needed for her bakery business. Balasan has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans, with soft conditions, to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Please help this young woman to continue her small business.

loans.use: to pay for materials and tools needed for her bakery

loans.name: Naser

texts.en: Naser is a 41-year-old man who is a father of four children. His only aim is to provide his family with a better life, as he is the only provider for them. Naser has been raising livestock for 13 years. His business was a good source of income for his family, as he expanded it step by step. Now he doesn't have enough money to buy food for his goats. For that reason, he has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy food for his goats

loans.name: Maa Taneswari Shg Group

texts.en:
Maa Taneswari Self Help Group consists of eight women from a village in Bhadrak district, Odisha. They formed a group to help themselves share their problems and solve their problems themselves. All the members are involved in different livelihood activities to support their family. 

One of them is Padmabati who was selected as the President of Maa Taneswari Self Help Group. The lady standing with her raised hand is Padmabati. Padmabati is 29 years old and is staying with her husband and her two children. She is involved in growing and selling vegetables in her village. Her husband is supporting her in this activity. She has requested a loan of 200,000 INR for her group. A portion of this loan will help her to purchase the required resources for vegetable cultivation. She says a portion of the loan will help her to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labor charges.

loans.use: to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Saeda Ali Group

texts.en:
This group is called Saeda Abdo. It is comprised of six women from Sana'a, Yemen. They are requesting a loan of 300,000 YER from AMB.

Saeda is the leader of the group. She is a 49-year-old widow with six children. Her oldest child is 25 years old and the youngest one is 10 years old.  She lives with her family in a rented house. Seada works as a cleaner in the private sector and she is a very dynamic woman. Her salary is very small and it is not enough to cover all the expenses of the family. Her husband accumulated a good amount of money and purchased a piece of land. His wife supported him with a lot of her money. Most of the land in the capital city of Sana'a is very expenses. The land cost Saeda and her husband a lot of money. They couldn't complete building their own house on the land that they purchased. Unfortunately, Saeda's husband passed away several years ago. This negatively affected the condition of the family. Recently, Saeda strove to build a house on that land. For this reason, Saeda applied for a loan of 60,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase construction materials to build her own house on the land that they purchased.

Saeda hopes to build her own house and live in it. She hopes to build more than one floor.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build her own house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell to the customers.

loans.name: Zahrat Al-Jabal Group

texts.en:
This group is called Zahrat Al-Jabal. It consists of four women from Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 120,000 YER from AMB.

Amina is the leader of the group. She is a 55-year-old married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 33 years old and the youngest child is 17 years old. She lives with her family in their own house in Sana'a. Amina is very active and dynamic woman. She is very talented and professional woman. The source of income of the family is from the renting of their house. 

Amina loves dressmaking and from this business she thinks that she will improve the living standards of the family. For this reason, she decided to work as a tailor. She has good experience in this business. Unfortunately; she doesn't have the necessary materials in order to start in this business. As a result, Amina is asking a loan of 30,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a sewing machine and sewing materials in order to sew clothes for the people in her area.

Amina looks forward to expanding her business more through opening a small shop for sewing. She hopes to provide her children with a secure future

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and sewing materials in order to sew the clothes for the people in her area.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her son's college expenses.

loans.name: Sonali Group

texts.en:
Suma, 46 years of age, is the leader of a group that hails near Fire station, Bhubaneswar of Khurda district of Odisha, India. Her family is comprised of her husband and two sons. The member standing first from left with raised hand is Suma. 

Suma’s younger son named Santosh is attending Govt. High School, Bhubaneswar. He has just passed into 9th class and wants to continue his studies. He is a bright student and wishes to do well in matriculation. For this Santosh has to take good tuition, which is not affordable by his parents from their present income.

The monthly income of Suma is about Rs.8,000 which is not at all sufficient to meet her monthly expenditures. The higher education of her son is now a financial burden. Hence she formed a group with three other members from her locality and applied for financial support from Mahashakti. It will be the first cycle loan for the group. From the loan Suma will pay the tuition fees and will purchase books for her son.

The three other members of her group, Monalisha, Hemalata and Pramila, also want a loan for the education of their children. In the photo every member’s child is standing in front of their respective mother.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees and to purchase books

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more products and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Alo

texts.en:
Alo is a 28-year-old married woman and together with her husband, is raising two sons. She has attended school up to grade five. She is married to Parimal. Her one son goes to school and is a student of grade one, while the other is too small to go to school. They are from a remote village of Maynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. 

Her husband is associated with a small business. Alo is engaged in livestock as an additional source of income for her family. She started this business a few years back, as she was unable to run her family with her husband's small income. 

Every day she gets up at early dawn, gets her son ready for school, does all the household work, and then looks after her animal husbandry. Alo is a very hardworking lady and has a great dedication in her work, with which she will be able to improve her family's wellbeing and provide a better future to her son. 

Now she is asking for a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS, to purchase another dairy cow with an aim to start a business of milk products. She hopes she will earn more profit from this business, as the products (butter, paneer, curd, cheese) are in great demand in her present local market. She plans to invest the profits in the future acquisition of more cattle. She also intends to save money for her sons’ future education. 

She is grateful to both BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow to start a dairy products supply business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more products and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Jorge Armando

texts.es:
Jorge Armando tiene 33 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, vive en casa de familiares junto su padre e hijos en el distrito de Cayaltí, una comunidad de clima variado, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

El brinda servicio de transporte mediante su mototaxi, trasladando a sus pasajeros a zonas aledañas a su distrito, junto con su esposa también se dedican a la crianza y venta de cuyes.

Jorge ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 000 nuevos soles para la compra de mayor cantidad de animales y compra de arreglos como alambre y carricillo para cercar el corral de sus animales y que le permitirá tener en mejor condiciones los mismos.
texts.en:
Jorge Armando is 33-years old. He is married and lives in his family's home with his father and children in Cayaltí District. The community is in an area with a varied climate. The people there make their livings in agriculture, commerce and raising livestock. The district is located in Chiclayo Province, which is a part of the Lambayeque Region on Perú's northern coast.

Jorge offers transportation services on his "mototaxi" (motorcycle taxi). He transports passengers to the areas surrounding his district. In addition, he and his wife earn their living raising and selling guinea pigs.

Jorge has requested a loan of 1 000 nuevos soles (USD $375) for the purchase of a larger quantity of animals and items like wire and bamboo to enclose his animal pen. This will allow him to keep his animals in better conditions.

loans.use: to purchase wire and bamboo to enclose his animal pen.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for five years.

Edna requested 14,000 PHP through NWTF to buy snacks, soap, sugar, and other groceries. 

In the future, Edna would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks, soap, sugar and other groceries.

loans.name: Ernesto Jose

texts.es:
Cada piñata que elabora Ernesto en su taller  cuenta con un toque único y especial. Él le transmite alegría y carisma a las piezas, lo que las hace atractivas a los ojos del público. Todos los días recibe con una inmensa sonrisa a los clientes que visitan su local diariamente  y los contagia con su espíritu optimista.  Además de  contar con ese negocio,  ejerce la profesión de profesor de español y física. 
Las ventas  marchan de maravilla, gracias a su esfuerzo  y a los detalles que aplica en las piezas. Ernesto desea  ampliar su negocio,  por lo que solicitó  un  financiamiento en KIVA MiCrédito, con el fin de expandirlo  y contar con más materiales necesita comprar: Papel Periodico, Papel Crepe, Papelografo entre otros para elaborar piñatas atractivas para todo tipo de eventos.  Si cuenta con muchos pedidos, necesitará mano de obra, lo que generará empleos a muchos jóvenes.
texts.en:
Each piñata Ernesto makes in his workshop is unique and special. He gives each of them a certain happiness and charisma, which makes them very attractive to the public. Everyday he receives customers with a big smile. His customers come to visit his workshop daily and they catch his contagious spirit of optimism. In addition to his piñata business, Ernesto is also a Spanish and physics professor.

Ernesto's piñata sales are going fantastically well, thanks to all of the effort and details he puts into each piece. He would like to increase the size of his business, which is why he is requesting a loan through MiCredito and Kiva. He needs to buy more materials such as newspaper, crepe paper, poster paper and others to make beautiful piñatas for all kinds of events. If he receives many orders, he will need to hire some help, which will generate employment for many young people.

loans.use: to buy newspaper, crepe paper, poster paper and other materials for his piñata business.

loans.name: Erlisa

texts.en:
Erlisa is 50 years old, married and has three children; one child attends school.

She raises pigs in the Philippines and requested 12,000 PHP through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Erlisa has raised pigs for two years and has previously borrowed three times from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a soap, toothpaste, biscuits and drinks.

loans.name: Santiago Manuel

texts.es:
Santiago es un hombre humilde y trabajador del campo. Vive en una finca en zona rural del municipio de Puerto Escondido, Córdoba desde hace más de 20 años.
Tiene cultivos de plátano y papa, cultivos que atiende todos los días y les dedica tiempo ya que es el único medio de ingresos que tiene para sobrevivir.
Como todo hombre campesino se levanta desde muy temprano en la mañana y termina sus labores en las horas de la tarde, tratando de cosechar buenos productos y venderlos en el mercado local.
El solicita un crédito para la compra de insumos agropecuarios y para el tratamiento de la tierra.
El crédito le brindara la oportunidad de mantener unos cultivos mucho más sanos y de mejor calidad. Su principal desafío es el alto costo de la manutención agropecuaria.
texts.en:
Santiago is a humble and hardworking countryman. He has been living in a farm in the rural area surrounding the municipality of Puerto Escondido, Córdoba department, for more than twenty years.

He has plantain and potato plantations and takes care of them every day. This is his only source of income. He starts working very early in the morning and finishes in the afternoon, as most people do in the countryside. He tries to harvest his produce and sell it at the local marketplace.

He is requesting a loan to buy agricultural supplies to work the land. This loan will help him to keep his crops healthy and to improve their quality. His main challenge is the high cost of the supplies.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase baby clothing, baby cream and baby oil.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
Doña Felipa es una mujer luchadora y muy trabajadora la cual se dedica al comercio y a la siembra y cultivo de papa. A sus 51 años de edad en ella en su juventud curso la primaria de forma completa teniendo la oportunidad de aprender a leer y escribir aunque la situación económica de sus padres no era la mejor por lo que se encuentra muy agradecida por tal apoyo. De su matrimonio tiene 4 hijos los cuales trabajan con ella en el campo apoyándole en los trabajos que requieren esfuerzo físico que ella a su edad no puede hacer. También cuenta con su pequeño negocio de pulperia situado en su casa de habitacion con el cual logra generar ingresos para cubrir necesidades básicas mientras sus cultivos de papa dan el resultado esperado. El terreno que en familia trabajan es herencia de su padre el cual está ubicada muy cerca de su casa de habitacion permitiendo esto estar más al pendiente de sus cultivos. 
Actualmente ella solicita apoyo financiero para la compra de insumos agrícolas para poder asistir la papa que piensa cultivar evitando de esa forma la propagación de plagas como la paratrioza y el producto se pueda dañar. Sus metas seguir incrementando su propiedad y mejorar la producción cada vez ya que los ingresos para ella y su familia dependen de este rubro.
texts.en:
Doña Felipa is a courageous and hardworking woman who owns her own business and also works planting and growing potatoes. She is 51, and although her parents were not well off economically she was able to complete elementary school as a child, which gave her the opportunity to learn to read and write. She is grateful to have had this support. 
Felipa has four children who work with her in the fields, helping her with tasks that require too much physical effort for her because of her age. She also runs a small grocery store from her home, from which she gets enough income to cover basic household expenses while her potato plants are growing. The land that the family farm is on is an inheritance from her father and is located very close to her house, which allows her to care for her plants well.
Felipa is asking for a loan in order to buy supplies for her farm so that she can attend to the potatoes she plans to grow and avoid the spread of harmful insects like the potato psyllid. Her goal is to continue to expand her property and improve her production because she and her family depend on the income from this farming activity.

loans.use: buy farm supplies to help her grow potatoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase jewelry chains, bracelets, makeup sets and earrings.

loans.name: Bibirajab

texts.ru: Бибирачаб 53 года. Она замужем за таксиста, у них двое сыновей и двое дочерей. Старший сын и старшая дочь обзаведены семьями. Бибирачаб живет со своей большой семьей в селе района Яван. Она на протяжении более 10 лет занимается животноводством. Бибирачаб разводит маленьких телят и бычков для продажи. Ей помогают муж и невестка. Одновременно их семья также занимается растениеводством. Чтобы увеличить поголовье скотов, Бибирачаб обратилась за кредитом. Она хочет таким образом увеличить доходность своего бизнеса и за счет прибыли купить приданое для дочери.
texts.en: Bibirajab is 53 years old. She is married to a taxi driver and has two sons and two daughters. Her oldest son and daughter are both married and have their own families. Bibirajab lives with her large family in Yavan region. She has been raising livestock for 10 years. Bibirajab raises calves and young bulls for sale. Her husband and daughter-in-law help out. The family also farms. In order to purchase more calves for her farm, Bibirajab has turned for a loan to KIVA. She hopes to increase her farm's profits with this venture and be able to buy dowry for her younger daughter.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Umedakhon

texts.ru:
Умедахон жительница района Яван, занимающаяся швейной деятельностью. Она умелая мастерица. Уже 12 лет как Умедахон берет заказы на пошив женских платьев национального покроя. Ее услуга всегда в спросе. Одновременно Умедахон еще и работает учительницей в школе. Она успешно совмещает обеи работы. Умедахон счастливая мать, у нее четверо детей в возрасте 9, 13, 14 и 15 лет. Муж работает в России. Все ее дочери учатся в школе, а также после занятий помогают матери в деятельности. Умедахон в данный момент нуждается в кредите. Она хочет купить необходимые швейные принадлежности. 
В будущем за счет прибыли она хочет провести ремонт в доме и улучшить условия проживания.
texts.en: Umedakhon lives in Yavan region and is a seamstress. She is a master of her trade. For 12 years Umedakhon has been making traditional Tajik dresses for sale and her services are always in demand. At the same time Umedakhon also works as a teacher at the local school. She successfully performs both jobs at the same time. Umedakhon is a happy mother of four children who are 9,13,14 and 15 years old. Her husband is a migrant worker in Russia. All of her daughters are attending school and help her mother around the house. Umedakhon currently needs a loan to purchase necessary sewing supplies for her business. In the future she hopes to use the profits from her business to repair her house and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase necessary sewing supplies.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a hardworking woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Palisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past 2 years, Hellen has been working hard to manage her food stall, where she sells vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Hellen has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more vegetables, and will help Hellen to generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her family. She hopes that in the future she will be able to start a retail shop. 

Hellen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret's group is comprised of hardworking women. Margret is 17 years old and lives in the town of Palisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Margret has been working hard to manage her clothing shop. 

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 750,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy clothes, and will help Margret to generate greater profits and pay her house rent. She hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a boutique. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase soap, toothpaste, biscuits and drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more onions, cooking oil and Maggi to expand her business.

loans.name: Mariley

texts.es:
Mariley vive en un sector muy deprimido del municipio de Sincelejo, en su casa, construida en bareque, vive con sus padres y 5 hijos pequeños. Ya que es separada debe llevar toda la obligación del hogar ella sola. Se gana la vida preparando pasteles de arroz y cerdo, alimentos típicos de la región que a los habitantes les gusta mucho, lleva 4 años en esta actividad y es la que le ha permitido tener un techo, que aunque es pequeño y en malas condiciones, vive en paz y con dignidad.
Hoy en día desea mejorar su negocio ya que estos pasteles los prepara en un fogón hecho en piedras y a base de leña, solicita un auxilio económico para la compra de utensilio de cocina como ollas y cucharones. Estos elementos le permitirán trabajar de una forma mas cómoda ya que los utensilios que en estos momentos tiene ya están en muy mal estado.
Su mayor sueño es poder darles un techo digno a sus hijos y construir una casa con buenos materiales. Es una mujer luchadora, con grandes ilusiones y con muchas ganas de salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mariley lives in an impoverished neighborhood of Sincelejo. She lives with her parents and five children in a house built with wattle and daub. She is separated, so she has to carry the weight all by herself. She makes a living selling rice-and-pork pies, which is a traditional dish popular with locals. She has been doing this for four years. This activity has helped her to have a roof over her head, and although she lives in humble conditions, she lives in peace and with dignity.

Mariley wants to improve her business. She prepares these pies in a wood-fired oven made with stones. She is requesting a loan to buy kitchen utensils such as pots and ladles. These utensils will help her to work more comfortably, because the ones she has now are in bad condition.

Her biggest dream is to give her children a dignified home built with solid materials. She is a hardworking woman with great goals in life and a strong will to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more onions, cooking oil and Maggi to expand her business.

loans.name: Jackline's Group

texts.en:
Jackline's group is comprised of hardworking women. Jackline is 18 years old and lives in the town of Palisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past 3 years, she has been working hard to manage her fish vending business. 

To help expand her business, Jackline has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish, and will help her to generate greater income and earn more profit. Jackline hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Jackline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase pure water, drinks and cigarettes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase assorted drinks and pure water.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more onions, cooking oil and Maggi to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothing, wax cotton and lace for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, biscuits and pure water.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more wood for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothing for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more onions, cooking oil and Maggi to expand her business.

loans.name: Negba Peace Group

texts.en:
These members are part of the group called Negba which consists of 5 female members. They make a living from various activities which have enabled them to improve their household finances. They live in different parts of Teshie. They sell fish, school bags, brukina (local drinks), and waakye (cooked rice and beans). 

Gifty is one of the group members. This is her fist loan. Gifty is married and has three grown children who are on their own. Her husband is a tailor and works from home. The house they live in belongs to family members. 

Gifty sells school bags. She has done this for 5 years. She works from Monday to Friday and uses the rest of the day to take care of her family.

The money from the loan will be used to buy a variety of bags to sell to customers. 

This group is asking for 2,000 GHS to support business.

loans.use: to buy a variety of school bags.

loans.name: Hailat

texts.en:
Hailat is a hardworking woman. She is 16 years old and lives in the town of Busia in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, Hailat has been working hard to manage her business, selling produce.

To help expand her business, Hailat has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy beans and maize, and will help Hailat to generate greater profits and provide for the family. She hopes that in the future she will be able to finish up her house. 

Hailat is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy beans and maize.

loans.name: Alima's Group

texts.en:
Alima's group is comprised of hardworking women. Alima is 19 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, she has been working hard to manage her clothing shop. 

To help expand her business, Alima has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help her to generate greater profits and pay her siblings' school fees. Alima hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a big boutique. 

Alima is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Flor Del Lago Santa Catarina Group

texts.en:
Santa Catarina is a small town on the shore of beautiful Lake Atitlan, Guatemala.   Tourists explore and buyartisan goods, school children play games during their recess breaks, and pickup trucks and tuc-tucs (small taxis) whizz by. 

Eleven women applied to receive another loan with Friendship Bridge. The group is called Flor del Lago Santa Catarina, which means Flowers of the Lake Santa Catarina. For many, it is their 10th or 15th loan. They chatter away in Kaqchikel (one of the many indigenous languages in the area) and anticipate with excitement the arrival of the loan officer and the opportunities he brings.  

Maria is 47 years old and has been a member of the Flor del Lago trust bank the longest.  Her business is buying and reselling typical Guatemalan goods such as huipiles (traditional blouses), textiles (such as tablecloths and tapestries), and bracelets. 

She requests a new loan to buy more textiles  and have a greater variety of goods to sell. She appreciates the investment that Friendship Bridge and Kiva investors are making in order to support her and the other members of the Flor del Lago trust bank. Maria says, “With this investment, my business will grow even more. It has changed the life of my family and it is a huge support.”

Maria didn’t have the opportunity to go to school. Unfortunately, this is the norm. Eight of the eleven women didn’t attend school at all and the other three only had minimal primary education. However, all of the women realize the importance of an education. Another woman in the group, Doña Virginia is a single mother and says, “Without Friendship Bridge, I wouldn’t be able to send my kids to school.  With this support, I can.” She happily reports that her four school-age children are in school.

Maria, Virgina and all of the women in Flor del Lago want to thank Kiva investors. They say it is a huge help and even though they can’t come to know everyone who invests in them, it makes them very happy that there are people who support them.

loans.use: to Increase her textile inventory

loans.name: Kotognokontala Group

texts.fr:
Kotognokontala est un regroupement de femmes de Hamdallaye Extension  de la ville de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans et ont au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, Bois de chauffage, Beurre de Karité, Savons, Soumbala  et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  deuxième prêt de groupe. 
Fanta est un membre du groupe Kotognokontala assise, deuxième personne de la gauche vers la droite, vendeuse de beurre de Karité. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de beurres de karité  en quantité et en qualité au fur et à mesure  qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse. Elle se procure au grand marché. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Kotognokontala comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 95 000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Fanta compte réaliser  110 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Kotognokontala is a group of women from Hamdallaye Extension  of the city of Koutiala who live in extended traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They are on average 47 years old and have at least five children each. 

This group of women sell various items such as firewood, karité butter, soap, soumbala (a local condiment) and others. To grow their activities, the members decided to join the lending program of Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second group loan.  

Fanta is a member of the group Kotognokontala who is seated, second person from left to right; she sells karité butter. She intends to use her loan to buy various amounts and grades of karité butter according to her retail sales to a diverse clientele. She buys her wares at the Grand Market.

Whereas the other members of the Kotognokontala group expect to make an average profit of 95,000 CFA each during this loan period, Mme Fanta thinks she will earn 110,000 F CFA. As well as reimbursing the loans, they will use a part of the profit to cover personal expenses and part to grow their working capital. 
 
They hope to see the partnership with Soro Yiriwaso flourish so that they won't run short of inventory.

loans.use: to buy Karité/shea butter

loans.name: Victo

texts.en:
Victo is a hardworking woman. She is 16 years old and lives in the town of Busia in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past year, Victo has been working hard to manage her business, selling produce. 

To help expand her business, Victo has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy groundnuts, beans and maize, and will help her to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Victo hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Victo is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts, beans and maize.

loans.name: Tano Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario lo integran cuatro socios, lo coordina el señor Estanilao de 66 años de edad y acompañado, se dedica a la comercialización de cosechas, sus principales clientes son de los países de Honduras y Costa Rica, el socio tiene tres ciclos de estar realizando préstamos en esta institución, y ha visto mejoras lo que le ha ayudado a aumentar sus ganancias, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de la cosecha de aguacate y mango de rosa, de modo que sus ingresos mejorarán. Las otras socias son las señoras Teresa de 37 años de edad dedicada a la hecha y venta de pinol y pinolillo en su domicilio desde hace diez años, María Auxiliadora de 23 años de edad dedicada al destace de cerdo desde hace cuatro años, y Joseling de 21 años de edad comerciante de ropa y calzado desde hace cuatro años.
texts.en:
This solidarity group is made up of four members and is coordinated by Estanilao, who is 66 years old and married. He works selling crops, and his major customers are in countries like Honduras and Costa Rica. He has completed three loan cycles with ADIM, which has allowed him to make improvements in his business that have helped him increase his profits. He is requesting this loan to buy avocado and mango crops. He hopes to improve his income.

The other members of the group are Teresa, who is 37 years old and has worked for ten years making and selling pinol [flour made from toasted maize] and pinolillo [a drink made from pinol] in her home; María Auxiliadora, who is 23 years old and has worked for four years butchering hogs; and Joseling, who is 21 years old and has worked for four years selling clothing and footwear.

loans.use: to buy avocado and mango crops to resell.

loans.name: Emmanuel Group
